description: Borrowed from Urdu بدمعاش‎ (badmāš), Hindi बदमाश (badmāś), and its source, Persian بدمعاش‎ (badma'âš), from بد‎ (bad, “bad, evil”) + معاش‎ (ma'âš, “life, livelihood”), ultimately from Arabic عَاشَ‎ (ʕāša, “to live”). Compare lowlife, which is a similar formation in English.

entries.meaning: (British India, South Asia) A rogue, ruffian or miscreant. [from 19th c.]
examples: ‘However big a badmash one is – if one's happy in consequence, that's some justification.’
